name: Pa'rus - A Living Canyon
description: This path follows the Virgin River through Zion's diverse riparian habitats, offering a close look at the plants and animals that thrive in this water-rich environment.

images.altText: A split-rail wooden fence running along a paved trail. Mountains are visible in the distance
images.title: A Living Canyon
images.caption: The Pa'rus Trail follows the Virgin River through lower Zion Canyon.

raw_body_text: A Living Canyon Learn Zion's diverse topography leads to a diversity of habitats and species. Along the Virgin River, the riparian area is home to plants and animals that require an abundant supply of water.

name: Kayenta Trail
description: The Kayenta Trail follows the Virgin River and provides panoramic views of Zion Canyon as it ascends toward the Emerald Pool Trails.

images.altText: A set of red sandstone stairs lined with loose rocks and green foliage leads out of frame.
images.title: Kayenta Trail
images.caption: Sandstone steps of the Kayenta Trail lead you up to the Emerald Pools

recent_reviews.author: Dylan Myers
recent_reviews.text: Beautiful trail with multiple waterfalls. This trail doesn’t include the upper falls but it’s about .5 miles off the trail

recent_reviews.author: Fangning Luo
recent_reviews.text: Begin from the Grotto then down from north to south can avoid the steep part. Could be crowded near the Zion lodge end.

recent_reviews.author: Sneha Gayen
recent_reviews.text: I did this yesterday and it was absolutely amazing! Such stunning views, 100% recommend.

recent_reviews.author: Beau Marchant
recent_reviews.text: Easy stroll! Great starter hike for your Zion journey.

recent_reviews.author: Uyen Campbell
recent_reviews.text: Not sure why this trail is rated moderate because there's no danger factor (no steep drop offs and ledges) so I'd rate it more on the easy side. On the distance and physical activity side it's moderate since it's long. It's a great way to get to Emerald Pools because you get some incredible views on the way. We went to Zion in mid Dec so shuttles weren't running, but that time of the year also means less crowds. We arrived at Zion Lodge (great food btw) at 9 am and had plenty of parking. Lucky to have warm weather while there (upper 50s) but it was chilly at the beginning of the hike (40s with wind).

recent_reviews.author: Anna Hipe
recent_reviews.text: Nice trail. Begins with a paved road and turns into dirt road as the trail ascends. There are steep sections but overall it's relatively easy. I love the view of the peaks from this trail as well as the Virgin River from below. It was nice and cool when you start in the morning and it's pretty shaded before the steep part. I recommend to start early to avoid the crowds. There wasn't much on the waterfall when we went but it is overall worth it to try.

name: Timber Creek Overlook
description: This short hike follows a rocky ridge with minimal elevation gain to a viewpoint offering stunning panoramas of Timber Creek, Kolob Terrace, and the Pine Valley Mountains.

images.altText: Red sandstone rocks with three hikers standing on them looking out over a valley. Blue, cloudy sky.
images.title: Timber Creek Overlook
images.caption: View from the Timber Creek Overlook.

name: La Verkin Creek Trail to Kolob Arch
description: This strenuous wilderness hike offers solitude and stunning views of the Kolob Canyons as it descends past Timber Creek to reach the massive Kolob Arch.

images.altText: Looking up at an orange-red sandstone arch on a cliff-face with clear blue skies overhead.
images.title: Kolob Arch
images.caption: The Kolob Arch is one of the world's largest natural arches.

name: Taylor Creek Trail
description: Follow the Middle Fork of Taylor Creek past historic homestead cabins into a narrow box canyon to see the impressive Double Arch Alcove carved into Navajo sandstone.

images.altText: Red sandstone cliff face with an alcove at the bottom and an arch above.
images.title: Double Arch Alcove on Taylor Creek
images.caption: The Double Arch Alcove marks the end of the Traylor Creek Trail.

name: Watchman Trail
description: This unpaved trail climbs from the river to a magnificent viewpoint overlooking the Watchman, lower Zion Canyon, and the Town of Springdale. Hikers will enjoy views of the Temples and Towers throughout the ascent.

images.altText: View from a sandy overlook of a triangular sandstone mountain with green foliage on the foothills.
images.title: Watchman Overlook
images.caption: View from the overlook at the end of Watchman Trail

name: West Rim to Scout Lookout
description: This strenuous hike crosses the Virgin River and ascends a series of steep switchbacks along the canyon wall to reach Scout Lookout. Hikers will enjoy dramatic views from a vantage point high above the floor of Zion Canyon.

images.altText: A hiker with an orange backpack standing on sandstone looks at the Angels Landing peak.
images.title: Scout Lookout
images.caption: Hiker on Scout Lookout looking towards Angels Landing and the Great White Throne.

name: Riverside Walk
description: This paved, relatively flat trail follows the Virgin River as the canyon's sheer sandstone walls narrow around you.

images.altText: Two hikers in blue jackets walk along a sandy trail lined with a wooden rail and fall foliage.
images.title: Riverside Walk
images.caption: Hikers on the Riverside Walk in autumn.

name: Middle Emerald Pools Trail
description: This moderate hike traverses an unpaved sandstone ledge above the Lower Emerald Pool, featuring a steep initial ascent that leads to expansive views of Zion Canyon.

images.altText: A pool of green water on a sandstone cliff surrounded by green foliage with a mountain in the back.
images.title: Middle Emerald Pools Trail
images.caption: View from the end of Middle Emerald Pools Trail.

name: Upper Emerald Pools Trail
description: Hikers climb stone steps through pinyon-juniper woodlands to reach the base of towering canyon walls featuring majestic seasonal waterfalls.

images.altText: A large group of people near a pool of water with green trees and an orange sandstone cliff face
images.title: Upper Emerald Pools in Summer
images.caption: Upper Emerald Pools

name: Lower Emerald Pool Trail
description: This paved trail winds through pinyon-juniper woodland, leading hikers to the Lower Emerald Pool and its scenic ephemeral waterfalls.

images.altText: A waterfall flows off of a sandstone ledge into a pool below, surrounded by foliage.
images.title: Lower Emerald Pool Trail
images.caption: View from the end of the Lower Emerald Pool Trail.

name: Grotto Trail
description: This level and shaded path follows the floor of Zion Canyon between the Zion Lodge and The Grotto, offering a gentle walk with excellent opportunities for wildlife viewing.

images.altText: A tan path crossing green grass into a stand of trees. A red sandstone mountain is to the left.
images.title: Grotto Trail
images.caption: View from the Grotto Trail

name: Pa'rus Trail
description: This scenic paved path follows the Virgin River, offering spectacular views of The Watchman and frequent wildlife sightings in the surrounding meadows.

images.altText: A tan, paved trail cuts through a meadow of yellow grasses toward a triangular sandstone mountain.
images.title: Pa'rus Trail
images.caption: View from the Pa'rus Trail as it follows the river between Canyon Junction and the Visitor Center.

name: Canyon Overlook
description: This trail traverses rocky terrain and sandstone steps above a dark slot canyon to reach a stunning viewpoint overlooking Pine Creek and lower Zion Canyon.

images.altText: Red sandstone slickrock dotted with green foliage with mountains in the background.
images.title: Canyon Overlook
images.caption: View looking towards the end of the Canyon Overlook Trail and the Towers and Temples of the Virgin

name: Angels Landing
description: This strenuous hike traverses a steep, narrow ridge with rock-carved steps and handrails made of chains while offering dramatic views and significant drop-offs.

images.altText: A hiker in a blue shirt holds onto chains as they traverse a sandstone cliff.
images.title: Hiker on Angels Landing
images.caption: Hiker holds onto the chains of the Angels Landing Trail.

recent_reviews.author: [Ani Kasamanyan](https://www.alltrails.com/members/ani-kasamanyan)
recent_reviews.text: The most amazing hike at Zion for the best views. Absolutely terrifyingly beautiful. Do NOT underestimate. Lots of opportunities to slip and fall. Make sure you are hiking with other people and that you are well prepared and have the right shoes.

recent_reviews.author: [a a](https://www.alltrails.com/members/a-a-2252)
recent_reviews.text: A few ice patches (on Jan 13), which you could walk around. However, there are a couple of spots without chain, which were uncomfortable for me because the rock covered in sand felt slippery. Turned back in the middle before the last climb. Someone on the trail wore micro spikes, they might work well with the soft rock for traction. Parking was scarce around noon, but a ranger helped to find spots

recent_reviews.author: [Manda Leo](https://www.alltrails.com/members/amanda-coelho-9)
recent_reviews.text:
If you’re thinking about doing it, do it it’s absolutely worth it. The first part of the hike up until you get past, Walter’s wiggle is the hardest because it is so steep. Then once you get past it the second part when you get to the chains it’s much easier, but it is definitely a mental challenge. There’s no other hike like it with an ending that is beyond rewarding. 

We went in January and we parked around 8 AM. There was plenty of parking at this hour. We had the trail basically to ourselves the whole time. We bought ice spikes, but didn’t end up needing them. 

Do it!!!!! And don’t look down lol

recent_reviews.author: [Hailey Bernstein](https://www.alltrails.com/members/hailey-bernstein-2)
recent_reviews.text: This trail was absolutely incredible. The mountains - I really haven’t seen anything like it. It’s definitely difficult and I was huffing and puffing at some points BUT making it up to angels landing was so worth it. it wasn’t as icy as I thought today and the weather was pretty good (almost no snow) and personally I didn’t use the shoe spikes I bought.

recent_reviews.author: [Stephaun Herring](https://www.alltrails.com/members/stephaun-herring)
recent_reviews.text: Small amount of ice on the trail. Hiked it without micro spikes without issue though. Not crowded at all either, great views.

recent_reviews.author: [Curtis Batchelor](https://www.alltrails.com/members/curtis-batchelor)
recent_reviews.text:
Did a winter ascent after it snowed the previous day. Definitely ask rangers for trail conditions and plan according if going in the winter. Definitely recommend any type of hiking shoes or boots with some type of traction device, I.e. micro-spikes, crampons, etc. If there is ice and snow on the trail and top I would definitely reconsider if not properly equipped.
Great views if you make it to the end though. Stay safe.

recent_reviews.author: [Russell V](https://www.alltrails.com/members/russell-verceles)
recent_reviews.text: Amazing hike!!! Angels Landing is all that! Steep hike to Scott's Outlook. Reminiscent of Grand Canyon except the trail is mostly paved going up. I guess not having to fight boulders and large steps are a plus!!! Met some great people on the hike. Really enjoyed it!! There is a ranger checking to see if you have a permit to go up angels landing. Its a lottery system to apply the day prior by 3pm. Luckily I got it! :) have a great Wednesday all!!

recent_reviews.author: [Koyena Biswas](https://www.alltrails.com/members/koyena-biswas)
recent_reviews.text:
One of the best hikes I have done. The trail is thoughtfully made and maintained. There is a diverse set of challenges throughout the hike and the difficulty increases gradually. The first couple miles are straightforward with multiple switchbacks gaining gradual altitude. The switchbacks get more and more challenging as you reach closer to Scout lookout.

Note: Despite of the straightforwardness of the first 2 miles, the gradual and consistent ascent could be challenging and cardio heavy.

Once you reach Scout lookout, the trail moves into Angels Landing (only with a permit that you have to get a day before - you cannot get a same day permit). There are clear boards indicating the trail. This part of the trail gets pretty challenging especially because of the steepness, exposure, and of course the fatigue of consistent ascent. Breathe and keep a consistent pace because at this point it feels like the trail never ends - primarily because you’ve been walking up for a minute by now. Be patient because the absolute beauty is coming soon! Take breaks at comfortable resting spots, but not for too long to lose momentum. There is a mix of short engaging problems in different sections and you will have to use some basic scrambling and climbing skills to get over. However, the trail is maintained to a level that it will never be confusing to know the correct path. Just keep following the chain rails.

You will not regret the walk up once you make it to the top. The last 0.5 miles are challenging, but the challenge makes it even more rewarding!

The descent might feel condescending given having the knowledge and memory of the difficulty when hiking up. But to me, it was surprisingly easier than the ascent. Use the chains more when descending, turn around facing up while descending washed out sections, sit down as much as you need to keep the momentum. There are plenty resting spots too. The views are better when descending as you are facing the canyon all the way down! Every part of this hike comes with rewarding views!

Note: Wear hiking boots or approach shoes for a better experience. Do not wear running shoes or canvas. I saw a lot of people doing this trail in running shoes and I can assure you it’s a better experience with the right hiking boots and/ or approach shoes.

name: The Narrows
description: This strenuous hike follows the Virgin River through a narrow slot canyon where the riverbed itself serves as the trail over slippery, uneven rocks.

images.altText: Red sandstone canyon walls frame the blue water of the Virgin River below.
images.title: The Narrows
images.caption: View in The Narrows

recent_reviews.author: [Kimmy Bennett](https://www.alltrails.com/members/kimmy-bennett)
recent_reviews.text: Pretty walk down towards the narrows. Luckily when we went not too crowded to be able to snap some shots of where Narrows starts. Went down off the paved path and walked around the river -very nice. We got some pretty views of the Virgin river

recent_reviews.author: [Nikitas + Cowboy](https://www.alltrails.com/members/nikitas-ballas)
recent_reviews.text: Zion the Narrows

recent_reviews.author: [Ed Simons](https://www.alltrails.com/members/ed-simons)
recent_reviews.text: Some great views with the sun shining on the rock formations. The water was little to high for me at about ankle level

recent_reviews.author: [Shan Liu](https://www.alltrails.com/members/shan-liu-19)
recent_reviews.text: Hey here early as parking filled up fast. Easy trail, awesome views.

recent_reviews.author: [Andres Wade](https://www.alltrails.com/members/andres-wade)
recent_reviews.text: Very beautiful, I reached the entrance to the Narrows Canyon, but since it's winter, I couldn't finish because the water is too cold.

recent_reviews.author: [Matthew Hunter](https://www.alltrails.com/members/matthew-hunter-11)
recent_reviews.text: Was on the first Springdale bus at 805 from my hotel. Hike was not super crowded. Took my three kids and thr 4yo made it about a mile into the Narrows before we turned around. The kids all had dry suits. The deepest water in the first mile was about 2-3 ft if you consciously try and stay to the shallow parts. By the time we were walking back towards the start of the hike it was getting pretty crowded (1030-11ish?).

recent_reviews.author: [Stuti Rawat](https://www.alltrails.com/members/stuti-rawat)
recent_reviews.text: A pleasant and easy riverside stroll leading up to the start of The Narrows. Even if you aren't tackling the main Narrows hike, this is a lovely path with easy access to the water in a few areas—just a short step off the trail. It's an easy walk for all skill levels. Expect heavy foot traffic since it's a main access point for The Narrows. Wildlife is a bonus! Look for squirrels and maybe even bighorn sheep near the cliffs.

recent_reviews.author: [Mary Gronik](https://www.alltrails.com/members/mary-gronik)
recent_reviews.text: This was a beautiful hike in its own right, even if you decide not to continue into the Virgin River for the wet hike. We planned to only do this trail but couldn't resist continuing on through the narrows once we saw it. Definitely bring a tall wood walking stick if you plan to go in the river - very slippery. Trail was beautifully maintained, super easy, lots of beauty along the way. Highly recommend!
